Hi Martin,

You may be interested in some of our work. In 2010, we developp=
ed an
evolutionary algorithm for robotics (termed "MEDEA") that was very mu=
ch
inspired by TIERRA, except that we were targetting open-ended evolution
=
with real robots.

The goal was to endow a group of mobile robots to be abl=
e to survive in
open, a priori unknown, environment. Mostly, it is a distri=
buted online
embodied evolutionary algorithm, where the fitness function is=
 replaced by
a selection pressure towards robots which are able to spread t=
heir genome
to other robots. As with TIERRA, the selection pressure comes f=
rom the
environment (ie. the genomes are in competition for a limited numbe=
r of
robots -- as was TIERRA's programs competing for memory space), and we=

tested it both in simulation and with up to 20 real e-puck robots. Though
=
the evolutionary dynamics are not so complex as with TIERRA (e.g. no
parasi=
tism), this is, to the extent of my knowledge, the only
environment-driven =
(as opposed to objective-driven) evolutionary robotics
experiment with real=
 robots.

If you are interested, you can check the following video:
https:/=
/www.youtube.com/watch?v=3D_ilRGcJN2nA

And if you are even more interested=
, you can read the following (all are
available from my publication
list<ht=
tp://pages.isir.upmc.fr/~bredeche/pmwiki/pmwiki.php?n=3DSite.MyPublications=
>
):

Bredeche, Montanier. Environment-driven Embodied Evolution in a Popul=
ation
of Autonomous Agents. PPSN, 2010. (link to
PDF<http://pages.isir.upmc=
.fr/~bredeche/MyBiblio/PPSN2010evolutionaryadaptation.pdf>
)
=3D> The origi=
nal description of the algorithm. experiments in simulation,
testing long-t=
erm adaptation with environment changes.

Bredeche, Montanier, Liu, Winfiel=
d. Environment-driven Distributed
Evolutionary Adaptation in a Population o=
f Autonomous Robotic Agents. MCMDS
2012. (link to PDF<http://pages.isir.upm=
c.fr/~bredeche/MyBiblio/2011-MCMDS-EvolutionaryAdaptation.pdf>
)
=3D> Exten=
sion of the previous. Experiments with 20 e-puck robots.
Experimental study=
 of the relation between population size and evolutionary
dynamics.

Montan=
ier, Bredeche. Evolution of Altruism and Spatial Dispersion: an
Artificial =
Evolutionary Ecology Approach. ECAL 2013. (link to
PDF<http://mitpress.mit.=
edu/sites/default/files/titles/content/ecal13/978-0-262-31709-2-ch040.pdf>
=
)
Montanier, Bredeche. Surviving the Tragedy of Commons: Emergence of

ism in a Population of Evolving Autonomous Agents. ECAL 2011. (link to
PDF<=
http://pages.isir.upmc.fr/~bredeche/MyBiblio/2011-ECAL-emergenceofaltruism.=
pdf>
)
=3D> These two papers are about using this algorithm to study the ev=
olution
of altruistic cooperation in challenging environment. Same algorith=
m,
different dynamics due to the environment. Experiments in simulation.

H=
aasdijk, Bredeche, Eiben. Combining Environment-Driven Adaptation and
Task-=
Driven Optimisation in Evolutionary Robotics. PLOS ONE, 2014 (to
appear).
=
=3D> This paper is a bit different as we step back from objective-free

-ended evolution and try to mix environment-driven adaptation with

e-driven evolutionary optimization. Experiments in simulation.
